results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Computer Networks | Miscellaneous | Question 16
results.question:
Consider the following statements:

(i) Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) provides a mapping from an IP address to the corresponding hardware (link-layer) address.

(ii) A single TCP segment from a sender S to a receiver R cannot carry both data from S to R and acknowledgement for a segment from R to S.

Which ONE of the following is CORRECT?

answers.answer: (i) is TRUE and (ii) is FALSE
(i) is FALSE and (ii) is TRUE

results.explanation:
ARP is used to map an IP address to its corresponding MAC address (hardware address) in a local network. This statement is TRUE.

(ii) statement is FALSE. TCP is a full-duplex protocol, meaning it allows simultaneous data transmission in both directions between the sender and receiver. A single TCP segment can carry both data and an acknowledgment. This is known as a piggybacked acknowledgment, where the receiver sends an acknowledgment for the received data along with its own data in the same segment.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Computer Networks | IPv4 Header | Question 18
results.question:
A machine receives an IPv4 datagram. The protocol field of the IPv4 header has the protocol number of a protocol X.

Which ONE of the following is NOT a possible candidate for X?
results.explanation:
The protocol field in the IPv4 header indicates the protocol used in the payload of the IP datagram.

  • ICMP (Option A) has a protocol number of 1.
  • IGMP (Option B) has a protocol number of 2.
  • OSPF (Option C) has a protocol number of 89.
  • RIP (Option D), however, is a routing protocol and works at a higher layer (Layer 3, using UDP at Layer 4), not directly indicated by the IPv4 protocol field. RIP typically uses UDP (Protocol 17) for communication, not its own protocol number in the IPv4 header.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Compiler Design | Miscellaneous | Question 21
results.question:
Consider the following statements about the use of backpatching in a compiler for intermediate code generation:

(I) Backpatching can be used to generate code for Boolean expression in one pass.

(II) Backpatching can be used to generate code for flow-of-control statements in one pass.

Which ONE of the following options is CORRECT?
results.explanation:
Backpatching is used to handle addresses or labels that are not yet known at the time of code generation, such as in the case of Boolean expressions. The compiler generates intermediate code with placeholders (e.g., jump addresses), which are later filled in with the correct values. This allows the code for Boolean expressions to be generated in one pass.

For flow-of-control statements (e.g., if, while, for), backpatching is also used to resolve jump targets or labels. The intermediate code can be generated with placeholders for the target of jumps, which are backpatched after the control flow structure is fully processed. This allows the flow-of-control code to be generated in one pass as well.

Thus, both statements (I) and (II) are correct, making the correct option (C).

answers.answer: Rule 1 is S-attributed and L-attributed; Rule 2 is S-attributed and not L-attributed; Rule 3 is neither S-attributed nor L-attributed

results.explanation:
MTU without IP header: 1500âˆ’20=1480 bytes

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | TOC | Undecidability | Question 25
results.question: Let ğº1, ğº2 be Context Free Grammars (CFGs) and ğ‘… be a regular expression. For a grammar ğº, let ğ¿(ğº) denote the language generated by ğº. Which ONE among the following questions is decidable?
results.explanation:
(A) Is L(G1) = L(G2)?

Undecidable. Determining if two context-free grammars (CFGs) generate the same language is undecidable. There is no algorithm that can decide whether two arbitrary CFGs generate the same language.

(B) Is L(G1) âˆ© L(G2) = âˆ…?

Undecidable. The intersection of two context-free languages is not necessarily context-free, and checking if two context-free languages have an empty intersection is undecidable. This is a generalization of the undecidability of the equivalence problem for CFGs.

(C) Is L(G1) = L(R)?

Undecidable. The equivalence of a context-free language (generated by a CFG) and a regular language (defined by a regular expression) is undecidable. Determining whether a CFG generates a language that is exactly the same as a regular language is undecidable.

(D) Is L(G1) = âˆ…?

Decidable. It is decidable whether the language generated by a context-free grammar G1 is empty. This can be determined by analyzing the grammar to check if there exists a derivation for any string. Specifically, this can be done by checking if there is any derivation starting from the start symbol and reaching a terminal string.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Operating Systems| CPU Scheduling | Question 26
results.question: Processes ğ‘ƒ1, ğ‘ƒ2, ğ‘ƒ3, ğ‘ƒ4 arrive in that order at times 0, 1, 2, and 8 milliseconds respectively, and have execution times of 10, 13, 6, and 9 milliseconds respectively. Shortest Remaining Time First (SRTF) algorithm is used as the CPU scheduling policy. Ignore context switching times. Which ONE of the following correctly gives the average turnaround time of the four processes in milliseconds?
results.explanation:
Process Arrival Time (AT) Burst Time (BT)  Completion Time (CT)   Turnaround Time (TAT = CT - AT)
P1  0 ms   10 ms         16 ms          16 - 0 = 16 ms
P2  1 ms   13 ms         38 ms          38 - 1 = 37 ms
P3  2 ms    6 ms          8 ms            8 - 2 = 6 ms
P4  8 ms    9 ms         25 ms          25 - 8 = 17 ms

Calculate Average Turnaround Time

TAT=CompletionTime(CT)âˆ’ArrivalTime(AT)

Average TAT=âˆ‘TAT / Total Processes= (16+37+6+17) / 4=76 / 4=19 ms

Final Answer:

The average turnaround time is 19 milliseconds.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Databases |  | Question 27
results.question: An audit of a banking transactions system has found that on an earlier occasion, two joint holders of account ğ´ attempted simultaneous transfers of Rs. 10000 each from account ğ´ to account ğµ. Both transactions read the same value, Rs. 11000, as the initial balance in ğ´ and were allowed to go through. ğµ was credited Rs. 10000 twice. ğ´ was debited only once and ended up with a balance of Rs. 1000. Which of the following properties is/are certain to have been violated by the system?
results.explanation:
• Isolation: The transactions were not properly isolated, leading to a race condition where both transactions read the same balance and proceeded without interference.
  • Consistency: The transactions violated the consistency property because the final state of the accounts was inconsistent. Account B was credited twice while account A was debited only once, resulting in an incorrect balance.

Therefore, both Consistency and Isolation were violated.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | C Programming | Loops & Conditionals | Question 33
results.question:
int x=126,y=105;

do {

if(x>y) x=x-y;

else y=y-x;

} while(x!=y);

results.explanation:
Initially, x = 126 and y = 105. The loop continues as long as x â‰  y, and in each iteration, it subtracts the smaller value from the larger one.

In the first iteration: Since x > y, x = x - y = 126 - 105 = 21.

Now x = 21 and y = 105. In the next iteration: y = y - x = 105 - 21 = 84.

The process continues until both values become equal, and at that point, the loop ends. After the loop, both x and y will be 21, which is the GCD of 126 and 105

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Digital Logic | Sequential Circuit | Question 34
results.question: In a 4-bit ripple counter, if the period of the waveform at the last flip-flop is 64 microseconds, then the frequency of the ripple counter in kHz is ________. (Answer in integer)
results.explanation:
Period at the last flip-flop = 64 microseconds.

The counter is a 4-bit ripple counter, meaning the frequency at each subsequent flip-flop is halved.
The period of the last flip-flop is given as 64 microseconds, or 64 Ã— 10â»â¶ seconds.

The frequency of the last flip-flop is the reciprocal of the period, which is 1 / (64 Ã— 10â»â¶) = 15,625 Hz.

Since this is a 4-bit ripple counter, the frequency of the counter is the frequency of the last flip-flop divided by 2â´ (because each flip-flop halves the frequency).

Thus, the frequency of the ripple counter is 15,625 Hz / 16 = 250 Hz.

Final answer: 250 Hz

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Computer Networks | Framing | Question 36
results.question: Suppose we are transmitting frames between two nodes using Stop-and-Wait protocol. The frame size is 3000 bits. The transmission rate of the channel is 2000 bps (bits/second) and the propagation delay between the two nodes is 100 milliseconds. Assume that the processing times at the source and destination are negligible. Also, assume that the size of the acknowledgement packet is negligible. Which ONE of the following most accurately gives the channel utilization for the above scenario in percentage?
results.explanation:
To calculate channel utilization in Stop-and-Wait protocol:

Frame size = 3000 bits

Transmission rate = 2000 bps

Propagation delay = 0.1 seconds

Acknowledgement size is negligible.

Transmission Time = Frame size / Transmission rate = 3000 / 2000 = 1.5 seconds.

Round Trip Time (RTT) = 2 Ã— Propagation delay = 2 Ã— 0.1 = 0.2 seconds.

Channel Utilization = Transmission Time / (Transmission Time + RTT) = 1.5 / (1.5 + 0.2) = 1.5 / 1.7 â‰ˆ 0.8823.

Convert to percentage: 0.8823 Ã— 100 = 88.23%.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Data Structures | Trees | Question 37
results.question: Let ğº be an edge-weighted undirected graph with positive edge weights. Suppose a positive constant ğ›¼ is added to the weight of every edge. Which ONE of the following statements is TRUE about the minimum spanning trees (MSTs) and shortest paths (SPs) in ğº before and after the edge weight update?

answers.answer: Every MST remains an MST, and every SP remains an SP.
MSTs need not remain MSTs, and every SP remains an SP.
Every MST remains an MST, and SPs need not remain SPs.
MSTs need not remain MSTs, and SPs need not remain SPs.

results.explanation:
Minimum Spanning Tree (MST): Adding a positive constant Î±\alphaÎ± to the weight of every edge does not affect the relative order of edge weights in the graph. Since the MST is determined by the relative weights of edges, the same set of edges will still form the MST after the weight update. Therefore, every MST remains an MST.

Shortest Paths (SP): For shortest paths, the absolute weight of each edge is crucial. Adding a constant Î±\alphaÎ± to all edge weights changes the shortest path calculations because the total path cost increases by a constant amount. Thus, the shortest paths may change, and SPs may not remain SPs.

Hence, (C) is the correct statement

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Engineering Mathematics | Linear Algebra | Question 44
results.question: .

answers.answer: The system ğ‘ƒğ‘‹ = ğ‘„ can be solved by first solving ğ¿ğ‘Œ = ğ‘„ and then ğ‘ˆğ‘‹ = Y
If ğ‘ƒ is invertible, then both ğ¿ and ğ‘ˆ are invertible.
If ğ‘ƒ is singular, then at least one of the diagonal elements of ğ‘ˆ is zero
If ğ‘ƒ is symmetric, then both ğ¿ and ğ‘ˆ are symmetric.

results.explanation:
(A) The system PX = Q can be solved by first solving LY = Q and then UX = Y.

  • This is True. The LU decomposition allows solving the system of linear equations in two steps:
    • First solve LY = Q (forward substitution).
    • Then solve UX = Y (backward substitution).

(B) If P is invertible, then both L and U are invertible.

  • This is True. If P is invertible, both L and U are also invertible. The determinant of P is the product of the determinants of L and U, and since P is invertible, neither L nor U can have a zero determinant.

(C) If P is singular, then at least one of the diagonal elements of U is zero.

  • This is True. If P is singular (i.e., det(P) = 0), then at least one of the diagonal elements of U must be zero, because the determinant of P is the product of the diagonal elements of U.

(D) If P is symmetric, then both L and U are symmetric.

  • This is False. If P is symmetric, it does not necessarily imply that L and U are symmetric. For L and U to be symmetric, they must be equal to their own transposes, which is not guaranteed by the symmetry of P.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Data Structures | Stack | Question 45
results.question:
Consider a stack data structure into which we can PUSH and POP records. Assume that each record pushed in the stack has a positive integer key and that all keys are distinct.

We wish to augment the stack data structure with an ğ‘‚(1) time MIN operation that returns a pointer to the record with smallest key present in the stack

1) without deleting the corresponding record, and

2) without increasing the complexities of the standard stack operations.

Which one or more of the following approach(es) can achieve it?

answers.answer: Keep with every record in the stack, a pointer to the record with the smallest key below it.
Keep a pointer to the record with the smallest key in the stack
Keep an auxiliary array in which the key values of the records in the stack are maintained in sorted order.
Keep a Min-Heap in which the key values of the records in the stack are maintained.

results.explanation:
(A) works because it keeps a pointer to the smallest key below each record, allowing the MIN operation to be performed in O(1) time without affecting PUSH and POP operations.

(B) would require updates to the minimum pointer during PUSH, making it inefficient.

(C) involves sorting, which would make PUSH operations take O(n log n) time.

(D) uses a Min-Heap, which increases the time complexity of PUSH and POP to O(log n).

Thus, (A) is the best solution.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | COA | Cache Memory | Question 55
results.question: Given a computing system with two levels of cache (L1 and L2) and a main memory. The first level (L1) cache access time is 1 nanosecond (ns) and the â€œhit rateâ€ for L1 cache is 90% while the processor is accessing the data from L1 cache. Whereas, for the second level (L2) cache, the â€œhit rateâ€ is 80% and the â€œmiss penaltyâ€ for transferring data from L2 cache to L1 cache is 10 ns. The â€œmiss penaltyâ€ for the data to be transferred from main memory to L2 cache is 100 ns. Then the average memory access time in this system in nanoseconds is ___________ . (rounded off to one decimal place)
results.explanation:
AMAT Formula: AMAT = L1 hit time + (L1 miss rate Ã— (L2 hit time + (L2 miss rate Ã— Miss penalty)))

Given:

L1 hit time = 1 ns

L1 miss rate = 0.10

L2 hit time = 0 ns

L2 miss rate = 0.20

Miss penalty = 100 ns

Calculation:

AMAT = 1 + 0.10 Ã— (0 + 0.20 Ã— 100)
AMAT = 1 + 0.10 Ã— 20
AMAT = 1 + 2
AMAT = 4 ns

Final Answer:
AMAT = 4.0 ns

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | COA | Pipelining & Hazards | Question 56
results.question: A 5-stage instruction pipeline has stage delays of 180, 250, 150, 170, and 250, respectively, in nanoseconds. The delay of an inter-stage latch is 10 nanoseconds. Assume that there are no pipeline stalls due to branches and other hazards. The time taken to process 1000 instructions in microseconds is __________ . (rounded off to two decimal places)
results.explanation:
The maximum stage delay is 250 ns. Adding the inter-stage latch delay of 10 ns gives a total time per instruction of 260 ns.

The first instruction takes the sum of all stage delays: 180 + 250 + 150 + 170 + 250 = 1000 ns.

The remaining 999 instructions each take 260 ns, so for 999 instructions, the total is 999 Ã— 260 ns = 259740 ns.

The total time is 1000 ns + 259740 ns = 260740 ns.

Converting to microseconds, 260740 ns = 260.74 microseconds.

In a B+ - tree where each node can hold at most four key values, a root to leaf path consists of the following nodes:

A = (49, 77, 83, -), B = (7, 19, 33, 44), C = (20*, 22*, 25*, 26*)

The *-marked keys signify that these are data entries in a leaf.

Assume that a pointer between keys ğ‘˜1 and ğ‘˜2 points to a subtree containing keys in [ğ‘˜1, ğ‘˜2), and that when a leaf is created, the smallest key in it is copied up into its parent.

A record with key value 23 is inserted into the B+ - tree.

The smallest key value in the parent of the leaf that contains 25* is __________. (Answer in integer)
results.explanation:
The key 23 will be inserted into the leaf node C, as it lies between 22 and 25. After insertion, C becomes (20, 22, 23, 25, 26). Since the leaf node can hold at most 4 entries, a split occurs. The middle key, 23, will be pushed up to the parent node (Node B).

Node B becomes (7, 19, 23, 33, 44), and it will split into two nodes. The middle key, 33, will be pushed up to Node A.

After the split, the smallest key in the parent of the leaf containing 25 is 33, which is the key pushed up from Node B.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | COA | Main Memory | Question 58
results.question: A computer system supports a logical address space of 232 bytes. It uses two-level hierarchical paging with a page size of 4096 bytes. A logical address is divided into a ğ‘-bit index to the outer page table, an offset within the page of the inner page table, and an offset within the desired page. Each entry of the inner page table uses eight bytes. All the pages in the system have the same size. The value of ğ‘ is ___________ . (Answer in integer)
results.explanation:
Page size = 4096 bytes = 212 bytes, so 12 bits are needed for the offset.

Logical address space = 232 bytes, so 32 bits are required for the address.

Entries in inner page table = 4096 bytes / 8 bytes per entry = 512 entries, requiring 9 bits to index.

Total address space = b (outer page table) + 9 (inner page table) + 12 (page offset) = 32 bits.

Solve for b: b = 32 - 9 - 12 = 11.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | TOC | Finite Automata | Question 60
results.question: Let Î£ = {1,2,3,4}. For ğ‘¥ âˆˆ Î£ âˆ— , let ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘‘(ğ‘¥) be the product of symbols in ğ‘¥ modulo 7. We take ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘‘(ğœ–) = 1, where ğœ– is the null string. For example, ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘‘(124) = (1 Ã— 2 Ã— 4) mod 7 = 1. Define ğ¿ = {ğ‘¥ âˆˆ Î£ âˆ— | ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘‘(ğ‘¥) = 2}. The number of states in a minimum state DFA for ğ¿ is ___________. (Answer in integer)
results.explanation:
The DFA needs to track the product of input symbols modulo 7, with possible remainders being 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Therefore, the DFA requires 7 states. The accepting state corresponds to prod(x) â‰¡ 2 (mod 7), so we need 6 states to track the product modulo 7.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | COA | Machine Instructions | Question 61
results.question: An application executes 6.4 Ã— 108 number of instructions in 6.3 seconds. There are four types of instructions, the details of which are given in the table. The duration of a clock cycle in nanoseconds is _________. (rounded off to one decimal place)
results.explanation:
The total clock cycles can be calculated as:

Total clock cycles = Sum of (CPI Ã— Instructions executed)

= (2 Ã— 2.25 Ã— 108) + (5 Ã— 1.20 Ã— 108) + (4 Ã— 1.65 Ã— 108) + (3 Ã— 1.30 Ã— 108)

= 4.5 Ã— 108 + 6.0 Ã— 108 + 6.6 Ã— 108 + 3.9 Ã— 108

= 21.0 Ã— 108 clock cycles

Step 2: Calculate clock cycle duration

Now, we calculate the clock cycle duration. The total time taken is 6.3 seconds, which is equal to 6.3 Ã— 109 nanoseconds. The duration of one clock cycle is:

Clock cycle duration = Total time in nanoseconds / Total clock cycles

= 6.3 Ã— 109 / 21.0 Ã— 108 = 3 nanoseconds

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | C Programming | Pointers | Question 62
results.question:
Consider the following C program:

#include

int main(){

int a;

int arr[5] = {30,50,10};

int *ptr; ptr = &arr[0] + 1;

a = *ptr; (*ptr)++; ptr++;

printf("%d", a + (*ptr) + arr[1]);

return 0; }

The output of the above program is ___________. (Answer in integer)
results.explanation:
arr[5] = {30, 50, 10, 0, 0}. The array is initialized with values 30, 50, and 10, the rest are 0.

ptr = &arr[0] + 1; sets ptr to point to arr[1] (value 50).

a = *ptr; sets a = 50.

(*ptr)++; increments arr[1] from 50 to 51.

ptr++; moves ptr to arr[2] (value 10).

a + (*ptr) + arr[1] becomes:

50 + 10 + 51 = 111

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | C Programming | Functions | Question 63
results.question:
Consider the following C program:

#include

int g(int n) {

return (n+10);

}

int f(int n) {

return g(n*2);

}

int main() {

int sum, n;

sum=0;

for (n=1; n<3; n++)

sum += g(f(n));

printf ("%d", sum);

return 0;

}

The output of the given C program is ________. (Answer in integer)
results.explanation:
For n = 1:

  • f(1) calls g(1 * 2) â†’ g(2).
  • g(2) returns 2 + 10 = 12.
  • sum += g(12) â†’ g(12) = 12 + 10 = 22.
  • sum = 22.

For n = 2:

  • f(2) calls g(2 * 2) â†’ g(4).
  • g(4) returns 4 + 10 = 14.
  • sum += g(14) â†’ g(14) = 14 + 10 = 24.
  • sum = 22 + 24 = 46.

Thus, the final value of sum is 46

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Engineering Mathematics | Probability & Statistics | Question 64
results.question: A quadratic polynomial (ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ›¼)(ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ›½) over complex numbers is said to be square invariant if (ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ›¼)(ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ›½) = (ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ›¼ 2 )(ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ›½ 2 ). Suppose from the set of all square invariant quadratic polynomials we choose one at random. The probability that the roots of the chosen polynomial are equal is __________. (rounded off to one decimal place)
results.explanation:
Expanding both sides of the equation:

(x - Î±)(x - Î²) = xÂ² - (Î± + Î²)x + Î±Î²

We substitute Î±Â² + Î²Â² = (Î± + Î²)Â² - 2Î±Î² into the equation, which simplifies to:

0 = (Î± + Î²)Â² - 3Î±Î²
For Î± = Î², the equation holds trivially.

For distinct roots, solving the system yields no real solutions other than the case where Î± = Î².

Thus, the probability that the roots of the chosen polynomial are equal is 0.5 since both possibilities (equal or distinct roots) are equally likely.

results.title: GATE | CS | 2025 | Set 2 | Discrete Mathematics | Set Theory | Question 65
results.question: The unit interval (0,1) is divided at a point chosen uniformly distributed over (0,1) in â„ into two disjoint subintervals. The expected length of the subinterval that contains 0.4 is ___________. (rounded off to two decimal places)
results.explanation:
The unit interval (0,1) is divided at a point x uniformly chosen from (0,1). The subinterval containing 0.4 will have a length of either x - 0.4 if x > 0.4 or 0.4 - x if x < 0.4.

The expected length is calculated by integrating over both cases, leading to an expected value of around 0.70 to 0.80
